posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
We got grant money to replace the donated desktops (now going on 12 years old) that we are using for programming. The existing desktops were pretty much for FRC programming and testing only; the new laptops would be used by FRC , FTC , and FLL .

The school IT department is being pretty insistent that these end up under the school domain control, and that the students use their domain accounts to log in. Additionally, they want to pull our existing laptops (the ones we use for competition) under school domain control.

I have shared the driver station best practices with them, pointing out items 8 (“Avoid managed Windows 10 or 11 installations from the school’s IT department.”) and 12 (“The Windows user account you use to drive must be a member of the Administrator group.”). That’s moved the bar a little, but I still have concerns.

Here are the issues I see:

for FRC , using the driver station requires admin access. We can get that on a couple of laptops used for driving at competitions, but I believe that testing code on roboRIO can’t be done from a student account, which is a pretty major impediment. I see this one as a show stopper.

right now, student written code ends up in the “developer” account on the PCs. If Joe and Jo are working together on stuff, and one of them doesn’t show up on a given night, the other one can still get to the code. If the code is under Jo or Joe’s documents directory, the other won’t be able to pick up the work. I believe this can be mitigated by using the public documents directory. Is this correct? Other solutions?

We’ve expressed concern about some of the policies that the school uses (timeouts, etc), but they are being receptive to those concerns, so fewer worries there.

Does anyone have any (successful) experience with running a large (4-6 students) programming team in an environment like this?

posts.name: Lyssia
posts.cooked:
fovea1959:

right now, student written code ends up in the “developer” account on the PCs. If Joe and Jo are working together on stuff, and one of them doesn’t show up on a given night, the other one can still get to the code. If the code is under Jo or Joe’s documents directory, the other won’t be able to pick up the work. I believe this can be mitigated by using the public documents directory. Is this correct? Other solutions?

you should strongly consider using git and github if you arent already instead of a shared folder. other than allowing multiple users/devices to work on a given project, it also helps keep track of changes and parallel work. these docs have some links to intros to git.

EDIT: to your main point, id still strongly prefer having non managed devices just for the sake of having more control over your dev environment. managed devices might not be an issue, but its going to be a real headache if they block something you need

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
So firstly, I’ll preface this by saying our team is from a very small school district and both the current and former Technology Directors are on our team, so this may not be the easiest thing to apply in your case:

We have used computers both with and without school domain images and haven’t run into many problems either way. In our case, we were able to get a team “Robotics” account created, which has the necessary administrator credentials to run the driver station and update software and so on.

One other benefit we’ve found to having a team account like this is that since the school district uses Google Drive, we have a central place we can store photos, videos, CAD, and code (though we do use Github for code primarily) and we don’t run into storage limitations.

I believe our current DS laptop is not on the domain (it’s newer and shipped with Win11, while the school still uses Win10) but the previous one was, and while we did have some issues with it, we don’t believe they were because of it being on the domain (more likely hardware). We only have a handful of programming laptops that we use (generally on the domain but used with the “robotics” account) and they’re pretty much only used for programming. For anything else, the students are generally using their own Chromebooks and domain accounts.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
We have a lot more issues around admin rights installing all the random Hardware drivers and disjointed packages and libraries then we do with the actual development and deployment process.

Specifically, the school dns blocks GitHub, so we had to come up with workarounds…

The school it department would be better off treating the laptops as guest devices restricted from interacting with most of their infrastructure then trying to manage them like a standard School issue laptop.

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked:
I will agree with the items brought up by the previous replies.  Having only domain account can cause issues, especially with connectivity with the robot and if on the Driver’s station then also with the FMS .  Specifically I would be more concerned about the FMS since weird DNS and Anti-Virus/Anti-Malware configurations can cause significant issues.

I would also immediately convert to using some form of source code management system (i.e. Github).  This is industry standard and should be taught to the students anyway.  Correctly using this can be a huge benifit to the team.

Enjoy!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
fovea1959:

for FRC , using the driver station requires admin access. We can get that on a couple of laptops used for driving at competitions, but I believe that testing code on roboRIO can’t be done from a student account, which is a pretty major impediment. I see this one as a show stopper.

This would be the primary concern.  Several things for FRC require admin access, the DS being the most obvious one.

Managed machines can really mess with the stability/flexibility needed for laptops brought to competition, so I would push back hard on that point and insist on those to be unmanaged machines.  Admin alone really isn’t enough for the driver station laptop, as domain policies (e.g. power settings) and mandatory installed services (e.g. custom firewalls, AV) can interfere with DS performance and cause control lag or field connection issues.  This extends past just the driver station machine–shared accounts are a must for other laptops at competition too; the last thing you need is for someone not to be able to log into a laptop at a competition because it can’t authenticate to the domain server.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Others have commented on using Github (or similar), and I fully agree. However, the OP did not actually state whether they do or don’t.  I will point out that the OP’s statement does not contradict using a cloud version control system.

We use Github and have team laptops with a shared account (although many people use their own). It happens a few times a year that someone (sometimes a Mentor) works on some code and forgets to push the changes at the end of the day, typically because things are broken, and then is not available the next session. Being able to track it down and then either continue or push is really helpful.

BTW, the one (?) distinct downside of shared accounts is that it typically messes with the version control log. Inevitably, “all” commits end up being from one account, because someone set up the laptop, and then Git just keeps using that name and credentials. There are plugins, but it is really easy to forget to switch Git accounts.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: We have to work heavily outside the school as they straight up don’t let us buy Ethernet equipment. I don’t wanna know what heart attack the school would have if we tell them that we have a few laptops that are completely outside the schools control. They provide a guest network that leaves most of the FRC websites unblocked so hopefully it’s just an unsaid agreement.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
Speaking as an FTAA and CSA here.

If you can avoid having your driver station (and a backup) under School domain control, if at all possible, do so.

I make a note of any team on practice day that has an IT-controlled driver station. More often than not I grab the field backup DS band bring it with me to their alliance station as soon as I hear it’s a connectivty issue.

Things that school IT does that can cause problems:

Disabling/locking of ports or devices Including: USB Ethernet Adapters “Unknown” devices

USB Ethernet Adapters

“Unknown” devices

Network Settings: Locking out manual TCP/IP settings Forcing a particular DNS server (either internally or local as part of antivirus) Enabling and locking firewalls on

Locking out manual TCP/IP settings

Forcing a particular DNS server (either internally or local as part of antivirus)

Enabling and locking firewalls on

Enforcing a windows update in the middle of an event.

The best advice I gave a team that had a particularly troublesome locked-down driver station. Inform the school that since they have these locked-down devices, they will need IT support on-site at the event to unlock/unblock issues as they arise.

Team showed up next year with a new DS , vanilla Windows 11, no managed domain.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
prensing:

BTW, the one (?) distinct downside of shared accounts is that it typically messes with the version control log. Inevitably, “all” commits end up being from one account, because someone set up the laptop, and then Git just keeps using that name and credentials. There are plugins, but it is really easy to forget to switch Git accounts.

This one we are already dealing with and have licked. We have a script that wipes the git username and email from the configuration at login. If people remember to logout at the end of the day, then the next person can’t commit until they going into the GUI and pick the correct name and email.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
(Putting on my Enterprise IT Security hat) If your school IT department wants to manage the machines you use in your lab/shop, my suggestion would be to make sure they are willing to work with you on creating the policy that is applied to those machines. Security done correctly should be a mild inconvenience, not a hindrance.

(Putting on my FTAA / CSA hat) That being said, the Driver Station machine you use at completion should not be managed. Try explaining to your school IT department that the laptop is only used to connect directly to the robot, and is never/very rarely connected to the Internet.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
FletcherS7:

If your school IT department wants to manage the machines you use in your lab/shop, my suggestion would be to make sure they are willing to work with you on creating the policy that is applied to those machines. Security done correctly should be a mild inconvenience, not a hindrance.

One of the things we discussed and resolved with school IT on a team I mentored was that in addition to team-owned computers, dozens of people brought in their personal computers to the shop.  What they ended up doing is setting up a separate VLAN for us with just an IP block and a gateway out to the internet (still filtered, but with a separate set of rules from the rest of the school).  It helped a lot to have an engaged principal on our side through the process!

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
apotato:

you should strongly consider using git and github if you arent already instead of a shared folder.

Floyd Moore:

I would also immediately convert to using some form of source code management system (i.e. Github). This is industry standard and should be taught to the students anyway. Correctly using this can be a huge benifit to the team.

We make extensive use of git and github. I ask the students to always commit and push at the end of day (which leads to a really messy git log), but sometimes that don’t happen (code is not always ready for a commit at the end of the day, students leave unexpectedly early).

If you are a team that only wants rolled-up-via-rebase commits in github (I would love to get there), then you still have to track down the local repository that has the intermediate commits to do the rebase and pull request.

We currently do not use shared folders, but a shared signon, but I’m trying to find a good way to conform to the school’s request to not have a shared signon.

posts.name: David Tian
posts.cooked: Here me out, Google Drive backup the folder where the code is stored. This might sound ridiculous, but as long as the computer has internet, the code should be backed up to drive. You will be able to access it when you need it as a last minute resort, but mainly your code is stored on github.
